title: Ezekiel Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 20.

questions.question: When did certain elders of Israel come to enquire of the LORD according to Ezekiel 20:1?
options: In the seventh year, fifth month, tenth day
In the first year, first month, first day
In the tenth year, seventh month, fifth day
In the fifth year, third month, twentieth day
questions.correctAnswer: In the seventh year, fifth month, tenth day
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:1 states that the elders came in the seventh year, fifth month, tenth day.

questions.question: What did the LORD say to Ezekiel regarding the elders enquiring of Him in Ezekiel 20:3?
options: I will not be enquired of by you
I will answer all your questions
I will bless you abundantly
I will give you victory over your enemies
questions.correctAnswer: I will not be enquired of by you
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:3 records the LORD saying He will not be enquired of by the elders.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20:5, where did God first make Himself known to the seed of the house of Jacob?
options: In the land of Egypt
In the wilderness
In the land of Canaan
In the mountain of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: In the land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:5 states God made Himself known to Israel in the land of Egypt.

questions.question: What land did God promise to bring Israel into as mentioned in Ezekiel 20:6?
options: A land flowing with milk and honey
A land of deserts and sands
A land of mountains and snow
A land of rivers and fish
questions.correctAnswer: A land flowing with milk and honey
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:6 describes the promised land as flowing with milk and honey.

questions.question: What did God command Israel to cast away according to Ezekiel 20:7?
options: The abominations of their eyes
Their clothes and shoes
Their weapons and shields
The manna from heaven
questions.correctAnswer: The abominations of their eyes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:7 commands Israel to cast away the abominations of their eyes and not defile themselves with idols.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 20:8 states that Israel obeyed God's commands and forsook the idols of Egypt.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:8 states that Israel rebelled and did not cast away their idols of Egypt.

questions.question: What did God give Israel in the wilderness according to Ezekiel 20:11?
options: His statutes and judgments
Gold and silver
Manna and quail
A new king
questions.correctAnswer: His statutes and judgments
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:11 says God gave them statutes and judgments in the wilderness.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20:12, what did God give to Israel as a sign between Him and them?
options: His sabbaths
His temple
His ark
His priests
questions.correctAnswer: His sabbaths
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:12 states that God gave the sabbaths as a sign between Him and Israel.

questions.question: What was Israel's attitude toward God's statutes and sabbaths in the wilderness according to Ezekiel 20:13?
options: They rebelled and polluted the sabbaths
They fully obeyed and kept sabbaths holy
They ignored the statutes but kept sabbaths
They forgot the statutes and celebrated sabbaths
questions.correctAnswer: They rebelled and polluted the sabbaths
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:13 says Israel rebelled, despised judgments, and greatly polluted the sabbaths.

questions.question: True or False: In Ezekiel 20:15, God lifted up His hand in the wilderness to bring Israel into the promised land.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:15 says God lifted up His hand that He would NOT bring them into the land because of their rebellion.

questions.question: What did God say to the children in the wilderness in Ezekiel 20:19?
options: Walk in my statutes and keep my judgments
Forget the past and build new idols
Return to Egypt and serve their gods
Prepare for war against their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Walk in my statutes and keep my judgments
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:19 commands the children to walk in God's statutes and keep His judgments.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20:25, what kind of statutes did God give to Israel because of their disobedience?
options: Statutes that were not good
Statutes of peace and prosperity
Statutes of blessings and health
Statutes of wealth and honor
questions.correctAnswer: Statutes that were not good
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:25 says God gave them statutes that were not good and judgments whereby they should not live.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 20:29 says the high place where Israel offered sacrifices is called ______ to this day.
options: Bamah
Zion
Gilgal
Bethel
questions.correctAnswer: Bamah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:29 identifies the high place as Bamah, where Israel offered sacrifices.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 20:31 states that God will be enquired of by the house of Israel despite their idolatry.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:31 says God will not be enquired of by Israel because of their idolatry.

questions.question: What will God do with Israel according to Ezekiel 20:34?
options: Bring them out from the people and gather them from the countries
Let them remain scattered forever
Destroy them completely
Send them to Egypt again
questions.correctAnswer: Bring them out from the people and gather them from the countries
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:34 promises God will bring Israel out and gather them with a mighty hand.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's commands. Based on Ezekiel 20, what biblical truth would you share about the importance of obedience?
options: Obedience to God’s statutes leads to life.
Obedience is optional if one prays enough.
Obedience does not affect our relationship with God.
Obedience is only for priests and elders.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s statutes leads to life.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:11, 13, and 21 emphasize that God gave statutes and judgments that if obeyed, one shall live by them, highlighting the vital role of obedience in the believer's life.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 20 teach us about God’s faithfulness despite Israel’s rebellion?
options: God spares and works for His name's sake, not destroying completely.
God immediately destroys those who sin.
God forgets His promises when people rebel.
God rewards rebellion with blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: God spares and works for His name's sake, not destroying completely.
questions.explanation: Verses 9, 14, and 22 show God refraining from destroying Israel because He wanted to protect His name before the nations, demonstrating His faithfulness despite their disobedience.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to follow worldly idols. According to Ezekiel 20, what should you counsel them about idolatry?
options: Idolatry pollutes and provokes God’s anger.
Idolatry is acceptable if done privately.
Idolatry is a cultural preference with no spiritual effect.
Idolatry only affects non-believers.
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry pollutes and provokes God’s anger.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:30-31 and 24 reveal that idolatry defiles the people and leads to God’s fury, warning believers to avoid it to maintain holiness and fellowship with God.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 20 say about the significance of the Sabbath for believers today?
options: The Sabbath is a sign of sanctification between God and His people.
The Sabbath was only for ancient Israel and has no meaning today.
Sabbath observance is a burden that God later removed.
The Sabbath is only important for priests.
questions.correctAnswer: The Sabbath is a sign of sanctification between God and His people.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:12 and 20 teach that the Sabbath was given as a sign to show that God sanctifies His people, underscoring its role as a symbol of God’s holiness and relationship with them.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged by their past sins. Based on Ezekiel 20, what hope can you share about God’s dealings with His people?
options: God pleads with His people and offers restoration despite rebellion.
God permanently rejects those who sin once.
God ignores those who repent.
God only accepts perfect people.
questions.correctAnswer: God pleads with His people and offers restoration despite rebellion.
questions.explanation: Verses 35-36 describe God pleading face to face with His people in the wilderness, showing His desire to restore and covenant with them even after their rebellion.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20, what does God promise to do for His scattered people in the last days?
options: Gather them from the nations with a mighty hand and bring them into their land.
Leave them scattered forever.
Make them serve other gods.
Ignore their plight.
questions.correctAnswer: Gather them from the nations with a mighty hand and bring them into their land.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:33-34, 41-42 explain God’s promise to gather Israel from the nations where they are scattered and bring them back to their land, demonstrating His faithfulness and power.

questions.question: A believer wonders about the consequences of polluting God’s holy name through disobedience. What teaching does Ezekiel 20 provide?
options: God’s name is to be kept holy, and disobedience pollutes His name leading to judgment.
God’s name is unaffected by human actions.
Disobedience glorifies God’s name.
God does not care about how His name is treated.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s name is to be kept holy, and disobedience pollutes His name leading to judgment.
questions.explanation: Verses 9, 14, and 22 emphasize that God acted to prevent His name from being polluted among the nations, showing the importance of honoring God’s name through obedience.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 20 teaches that God’s judgments and statutes are given so that people may live by them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:11, 13, and 21 clearly state that God’s statutes and judgments are intended to be obeyed so that one may live by them.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 20, God promises to bring judgment without any opportunity for repentance or restoration.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:35-37 shows God pleading face to face and bringing His people under the covenant, indicating His willingness to restore rather than only judge.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 20 teaches that God gave Israel ______ to be a sign between Him and them, that they might know He is the LORD who sanctifies them.
options: Sabbaths
Laws
Kings
Prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Sabbaths
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:12 and 20 state that God gave the sabbaths as a sign of sanctification to show that He is the LORD who sanctifies His people.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 20 illustrate the importance of humility and repentance in the face of sin?
options: By showing that upon returning to God’s land, Israel will remember their sins and loathe themselves.
By stating that sin has no consequences.
By encouraging pride in one's own righteousness.
By promising instant forgiveness without change.
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that upon returning to God’s land, Israel will remember their sins and loathe themselves.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:43 explains that when Israel returns, they will remember their defilement and feel remorse, teaching that humility and repentance are necessary parts of restoration.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance through trials can we learn from Ezekiel 20’s recounting of Israel’s wilderness experience?
options: God disciplines but does not destroy, giving opportunity to persist in obedience.
Trials mean God has abandoned His people.
Perseverance is not necessary if one feels weak.
God rewards those who avoid trials.
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines but does not destroy, giving opportunity to persist in obedience.
questions.explanation: Verses 17, 21, and 38 show that though God was angry and ready to punish, He spared Israel to discipline and refine them, highlighting perseverance amid trials.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20, how should believers approach serving God in community and fellowship?
options: Serve God with holy offerings and obedience in His holy mountain.
Serve God individually without regard to others.
Serve only when convenient.
Serve God by following cultural customs instead of His commands.
questions.correctAnswer: Serve God with holy offerings and obedience in His holy mountain.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:40-41 states that in God’s holy mountain, Israel will serve Him with offerings and holiness, emphasizing community worship and obedience.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 20 teach about God’s discipline in relation to parenting and teaching children?
options: Children are instructed not to follow the sinful ways of their fathers but to keep God’s statutes.
Children have no responsibility for their actions.
Parents should allow children to choose any path.
Discipline is unnecessary in spiritual matters.
questions.correctAnswer: Children are instructed not to follow the sinful ways of their fathers but to keep God’s statutes.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:18-19 instructs the children in the wilderness not to follow the sinful judgments of their fathers but to obey God’s statutes, highlighting the importance of teaching children godly living.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 20 encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in daily living?
options: By obeying God’s statutes and judgments which lead to life and blessing.
By compromising when convenient.
By following only cultural norms.
By ignoring God’s word.
questions.correctAnswer: By obeying God’s statutes and judgments which lead to life and blessing.
questions.explanation: Verses 11, 13, and 21 emphasize that following God’s statutes and judgments brings life, teaching believers to live with integrity and obedience.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 20.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 20:5-6, how does God describe His initial covenant with Israel in Egypt?
options: He lifted up His hand to the seed of Jacob and promised a land flowing with milk and honey
He commanded them to build idols and worship them
He rejected them for their idolatry immediately
He gave them the law on Mount Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: He lifted up His hand to the seed of Jacob and promised a land flowing with milk and honey
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:5-6 describes God lifting up His hand to the house of Jacob, promising to bring them out of Egypt to a land flowing with milk and honey, symbolizing His covenant and promise.

questions.question: What is the significance of the sabbaths given to Israel according to Ezekiel 20:12 and 20:20?
options: They are a sign between God and Israel to know that He sanctifies them
They were a day for offering sacrifices to idols
They were optional days of rest with no covenantal meaning
They symbolized Israel's independence from God
questions.correctAnswer: They are a sign between God and Israel to know that He sanctifies them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:12 and 20:20 emphasize the sabbaths as a covenantal sign showing that the LORD sanctifies Israel and that they should keep His statutes.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 20 portray Israel’s repeated rebellion in the wilderness?
options: They despised statutes, polluted sabbaths, and followed idols despite God's warnings
They faithfully kept God’s commandments without fault
They only rebelled once and then repented immediately
They rejected only the sabbaths but kept other laws
questions.correctAnswer: They despised statutes, polluted sabbaths, and followed idols despite God's warnings
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:13, 21, and 24 recount Israel’s persistent rebellion by despising God's statutes, polluting the sabbaths, and following idols.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 20:9 and 20:14 show that God acted to preserve His name's holiness before the heathen even when Israel rebelled.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Both verses highlight God’s action 'for my name’s sake' to prevent the pollution of His name among the nations, demonstrating His concern for divine holiness despite Israel’s sin.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 20:25 reveal about the statutes God gave Israel in response to their disobedience?
options: God gave them statutes that were not good and judgments by which they should not live
God gave them perfect laws to follow without fail
God revoked all the laws and left them without guidance
God gave them laws identical to those of surrounding nations
questions.correctAnswer: God gave them statutes that were not good and judgments by which they should not live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:25 indicates God gave Israel disobedient statutes as a form of judgment, reflecting a judicial hardening similar to Deuteronomy 28 curses.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'I lifted up mine hand' function in Ezekiel 20:5, 15, 23, and 42?
options: As an oath signifying God's solemn promise or judgment
As a gesture of dismissal toward Israel
As a sign of blessing without any legal weight
As a reference to a physical act of blessing Moses only
questions.correctAnswer: As an oath signifying God's solemn promise or judgment
questions.explanation: In Ezekiel 20, 'I lifted up mine hand' is a Hebrew idiom indicating a solemn oath by God either promising the land or pronouncing judgment (verses 5, 15, 23, 42).

questions.question: What cultural practice is condemned in Ezekiel 20:26 and 31 that involved 'passing through the fire'?
options: Child sacrifice to pagan gods
Celebration of harvest festivals
Annual purification rites of the temple
Peace offerings to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Child sacrifice to pagan gods
questions.explanation: The phrase 'passing through the fire' in Ezekiel 20:26 and 31 refers to idolatrous practices, likely child sacrifice, common in ancient Near Eastern religions and condemned by the LORD.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20:33-34, what method will God use to restore Israel from the nations where they are scattered?
options: With a mighty hand, a stretched out arm, and fury poured out
Through peaceful diplomatic negotiation
By sending prophets only
By allowing them to return on their own initiative
questions.correctAnswer: With a mighty hand, a stretched out arm, and fury poured out
questions.explanation: These verses use imagery of divine power and judgment, echoing Exodus language, to describe God's sovereign and forceful restoration of Israel.

questions.question: What is the literary device used in Ezekiel 20:35-36 where God will 'plead with you face to face' like He did in the wilderness?
options: Typology, foreshadowing a covenant renewal
Parable illustrating agricultural cycles
Irony indicating God’s rejection
Allegory for political exile
questions.correctAnswer: Typology, foreshadowing a covenant renewal
questions.explanation: This passage typologically echoes the wilderness covenant experience, foreshadowing a future intimate covenant renewal between God and Israel.

questions.question: True or False: The elders of Israel came to Ezekiel to inquire of the LORD, but God declared He would not be enquired of by them (Ezekiel 20:3, 31).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:3 and 31 show God’s refusal to be enquired of due to Israel’s persistent rebellion and idolatry, highlighting broken relationship and judgment.

questions.question: What does the term 'Bamah' in Ezekiel 20:29 refer to in the historical and cultural context of ancient Israel?
options: A high place or elevated site used for pagan worship
The name of a prophet who opposed idolatry
A type of sacrificial lamb
A festival celebrating the harvest
questions.correctAnswer: A high place or elevated site used for pagan worship
questions.explanation: The word 'Bamah' means 'high place' and was often associated with illicit worship on hills, condemned in Israel’s covenant history.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 20:37-38, what is the significance of Israel 'passing under the rod' and being purged of rebels?
options: It symbolizes God's discipline and purification to establish covenant faithfulness
It refers to a literal shepherding practice in the wilderness
It indicates the immediate destruction of all Israel
It means the removal of foreign nations from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's discipline and purification to establish covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: The rod is a symbol of shepherd’s discipline; God uses this metaphor to describe purging rebels and restoring covenant order.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 20:40-41 connect the theme of restoration with the concept of God’s 'holy mountain'?
options: God promises Israel will serve Him there and He will accept their offerings, sanctifying them before the nations
It describes the destruction of the mountain by fire
It indicates that the mountain will be given to the heathen
It shows that Israel will never return to the mountain
questions.correctAnswer: God promises Israel will serve Him there and He will accept their offerings, sanctifying them before the nations
questions.explanation: These verses affirm the eschatological hope of worship and divine acceptance on God's holy mountain, symbolizing restoration and sanctification.

questions.question: What is the significance of the fire kindled in the forest of the south described in Ezekiel 20:47-48?
options: It symbolizes God’s judgment consuming all, both green and dry trees, indicating comprehensive destruction
It represents a cleansing ritual for the Israelites
It is a metaphor for a festival of lights
It predicts a natural wildfire with no divine implication
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God’s judgment consuming all, both green and dry trees, indicating comprehensive destruction
questions.explanation: The unquenchable fire metaphorically represents God's inescapable judgment on all, illustrating total purification or destruction.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20:32, what folly do the Israelites contemplate that God condemns?
options: To be like the heathen and serve wood and stone idols
To build a temple in their own image
To abandon their land and live in exile voluntarily
To blend their customs with those of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To be like the heathen and serve wood and stone idols
questions.explanation: God condemns their desire to assimilate with pagan nations by worshiping lifeless idols, which is futile and condemned throughout Scripture.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20, why did God choose to bring Israel out of Egypt despite their rebellion?
options: To preserve His name from pollution among the nations
To reward their obedience
To give them riches and power
To make them a great army
questions.correctAnswer: To preserve His name from pollution among the nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:9 states that God worked for His name's sake so it would not be polluted before the heathen among whom He made Himself known by bringing Israel out of Egypt. This reflects God's holiness and faithfulness to His covenant, consistent with Exodus 34:5-7 and Isaiah 48:9-11. The New Testament also affirms God's faithfulness to His name in Romans 3:3-4.

questions.question: What was the purpose of giving the sabbaths to Israel according to Ezekiel 20?
options: To be a sign between God and His people
To provide rest from labor
To commemorate the Exodus only
To separate priests from the people
questions.correctAnswer: To be a sign between God and His people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:12 explains that the sabbaths were given to be a sign so that Israel might know the LORD who sanctifies them. This sign function is echoed in Exodus 31:13 and Hebrews 4:9-10, showing the sabbath as a covenantal sign of holiness and relationship with God.

questions.question: What was the consequence mentioned in Ezekiel 20 for Israel's pollution of the sabbaths and rebellion?
options: God would pour out His fury and scatter them among the nations
God would immediately destroy them
God would give them a new land
God would establish a king for them
questions.correctAnswer: God would pour out His fury and scatter them among the nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:23 states God lifted His hand to scatter Israel among the nations because they despised His statutes and polluted His sabbaths. This judgment aligns with Deuteronomy 28:64 and Jeremiah 9:16. The prophetic warning of exile is consistent with the theme of divine discipline for covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 20, what did God say about the statutes given that were "not good"?
options: They were given because Israel rejected God's good statutes
They were meant to bless Israel
They were secret laws for the priests
They were eternal and unchanging
questions.correctAnswer: They were given because Israel rejected God's good statutes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:25 explains that God gave statutes that were not good because Israel had rejected His good statutes and judgments. This reflects God's righteous judgment and allowance of consequences for sin, consistent with Deuteronomy 28:15-68 and Romans 1:24-28 which speak of God giving people up to their sinful desires as judgment.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 20 teach about God's attitude toward Israel despite their repeated rebellion?
options: God withholds complete destruction for the sake of His name
God immediately destroys them without mercy
God ignores their sins
God condones their idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: God withholds complete destruction for the sake of His name
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:17 shows that God's eye spared Israel from destruction in the wilderness, not ending them completely. This restraint is for His name’s sake as also seen in Exodus 34:7 and Psalm 78:38. The New Testament emphasizes God's mercy despite sin in Romans 2:4 and 2 Peter 3:9.

questions.question: What does God command the children of Israel in the wilderness regarding their fathers' statutes and idols in Ezekiel 20?
options: Not to walk in their statutes nor defile themselves with their idols
To follow their fathers' statutes faithfully
To worship the idols alongside God
To ignore all statutes
questions.correctAnswer: Not to walk in their statutes nor defile themselves with their idols
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:18 commands the children not to walk in the statutes of their fathers or defile themselves with their idols but to walk in God's statutes. This call to reject inherited sin echoes Deuteronomy 12:29-31 and Isaiah 44:9-20. The New Testament calls believers to put off the old self and idols in Ephesians 4:22-24.

questions.question: How does God describe His future rule over Israel in Ezekiel 20?
options: With a mighty hand, a stretched out arm, and with fury poured out
With gentleness and silence
Through human kings only
By allowing Israel to self-govern
questions.correctAnswer: With a mighty hand, a stretched out arm, and with fury poured out
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:33 describes God's rule over Israel as with a mighty hand, stretched out arm, and fury poured out. This imagery recalls Exodus 6:6 and Isaiah 63:9-10, highlighting God's sovereign, powerful, and sometimes wrathful governance. The New Testament also affirms God's authoritative rule in Revelation 19:15.

questions.question: What is the significance of the wilderness in God's dealings with Israel as described in Ezekiel 20?
options: It is the place where God pleads with Israel face to face
It is where Israel prospers and multiplies
It is where Israel builds their temples
It is where Israel conquers their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It is the place where God pleads with Israel face to face
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:35-36 states that God will bring Israel into the wilderness and plead with them face to face, similar to how He pleaded with their fathers. This wilderness encounter symbolizes covenant testing and renewal (Exodus 32:11-14; Deuteronomy 8:2). The wilderness is a place of divine discipline and revelation.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 20 say about Israel's idolatry and making their sons pass through the fire?
options: It is a pollution and a trespass against the LORD
It is an acceptable cultural practice
It honors God
It is never mentioned
questions.correctAnswer: It is a pollution and a trespass against the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:31 describes Israel's idolatry and making their sons pass through the fire as polluting themselves and committing trespass against God. This condemns child sacrifice and idolatry, consistent with Leviticus 18:21, Deuteronomy 12:31, and Jeremiah 7:31. The New Testament condemns idolatry as sin in 1 Corinthians 10:14.

questions.question: What promise does God make concerning the regathering of Israel in Ezekiel 20?
options: He will bring them out of the countries where they are scattered with mighty hand and fury poured out
He will abandon them forever
He will give them a new king immediately
He will merge them with other nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will bring them out of the countries where they are scattered with mighty hand and fury poured out
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:34 promises God will gather Israel from the nations where they are scattered with mighty hand and fury poured out. This is a messianic and eschatological promise of restoration found also in Jeremiah 23:3-8 and Ezekiel 37:21-22. The New Testament sees this fulfilled ultimately in Christ (Romans 11:26).

questions.question: What is the 'high place' called in Ezekiel 20 where Israel offered sacrifices that provoked God?
options: Bamah
Gilgal
Bethel
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Bamah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:29 identifies the high place where Israel offered sacrifices as 'Bamah,' a place of idolatrous worship. This term and concept are condemned elsewhere (1 Kings 3:2; 2 Kings 17:10). It illustrates the syncretism and covenant unfaithfulness of Israel, contrasting with the true worship God requires (John 4:23-24).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 20, what will happen to the rebels and transgressors among Israel after the covenant renewal?
options: They will be purged and not enter the land of Israel
They will be exalted as leaders
They will receive special blessings
They will be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: They will be purged and not enter the land of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:38 states God will purge rebels and transgressors and they shall not enter the land of Israel. This purification is part of covenant faithfulness and holiness (Exodus 19:5-6; Deuteronomy 7:9). The New Testament emphasizes holiness and separation from sin in 1 Corinthians 6:9-11.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 20 say about the people serving idols and polluting God's holy name?
options: They may continue to serve idols but must not pollute God's name with gifts
They are free to do as they please without consequence
They are praised for their offerings
They will be rewarded for tolerance
questions.correctAnswer: They may continue to serve idols but must not pollute God's name with gifts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:39 permits Israel to serve idols but commands them not to pollute God's holy name with their gifts and idols. This highlights God's holiness and concern for His reputation (Leviticus 10:3; Ezekiel 36:23). It underscores that idolatry defiles the covenant relationship and God's name.

questions.question: What will God require from all Israel when they serve Him in His holy mountain according to Ezekiel 20?
options: Offerings, firstfruits, and all holy things
Only verbal worship
No offerings
Sacrifices of animals only
questions.correctAnswer: Offerings, firstfruits, and all holy things
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:40 reveals God will require offerings, firstfruits, and all holy things from Israel on His holy mountain. This aligns with the covenantal sacrificial system (Leviticus 1-7; Deuteronomy 26:1-11) and anticipates the true temple worship fulfilled in Christ (Hebrews 10:1-18).

questions.question: What is the ultimate purpose of God's actions and judgments toward Israel as stated in Ezekiel 20?
options: That Israel and the nations know that He is the LORD
To show God's indifference
To promote Israel's political power
To establish multiple gods
questions.correctAnswer: That Israel and the nations know that He is the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 20:38 and 20:42 emphasize that through His actions, Israel and the nations will know that He is the LORD. This reveals God's desire for His glory and recognition of His sovereignty, consistent with Exodus 9:16 and Isaiah 43:10-12. The New Testament affirms God's glory revealed in Christ (John 17:1).
